thread.title: Matt Harvey masterful as Mets beat Cubs, 4-2, in NLCS Game 1
thread.title_full: Matt Harvey masterful as Mets beat Cubs, 4-2, in NLCS Game 1

title: Matt Harvey masterful as Mets beat Cubs, 4-2, in NLCS Game 1
text:
Matt Harvey masterful as Mets beat Cubs, 4-2, in NLCS Game 1 Updated October 17, 2015 11:17 PM By MARC CARIG marc.carig@newsday.com 
advertisement | advertise on newsday 
Matt Harvey, owner of the right elbow that launched a thousand tirades, sprinted to the mound in the first inning. He couldn't wait to get started. 
Debates have raged about his propensity to make headlines, his punctuality on workout days, his desire to protect his precious right arm at the urging of agent Scott Boras. Controversy has obscured his immense talent. Latest Mets stories Mets, Jets, Rangers all home on fluky Sunday 
But on Saturday night, in the Mets' 4-2 victory over the Cubs in Game 1 of the National League Championship Series, there would be no forgetting why the Mets endured great pains to ensure that he would be ready for his moment. Harvey made sure of it. See also Boxscore: Mets vs. Cubs NLCS Game 1 Database Matt Harvey's career starts Database Citi Field HRs 
In his second postseason start, Harvey limited the Cubs to two runs and four hits in 72/3 innings. He departed after allowing Kyle Schwarber's fourth homer of the postseason, a solo shot that landed deep in the Cubs' bullpen. Still, he walked off to a rousing ovation with the Mets ahead 4-2. 
Two days after pitching the last two innings of the NLDS-clinching win over the Dodgers, Jeurys Familia recorded the final four outs against the Cubs. He has retired 20 of the 22 batters he has faced in the postseason. 
Daniel Murphy hit his fourth homer of the postseason, blasting an 87-mph cutter from Jon Lester for a solo shot that hit the facing of the upper deck in right. 
advertisement | advertise on newsday 
Curtis Granderson knocked in a pair of runs with a two-out RBI single in the fifth to snap a 1-1 tie and a sacrifice fly in the seventh. 
And Travis d'Arnaud hammered a towering solo shot in the sixth that bounced off the top of the Home Run Apple in straightaway centerfield. Mets NLCS Game 1: Mets vs. Cubs 
The outburst came on a night in which Harvey flashed near-total command of his arsenal and reminded a fan base why they had come to lean on him in the first place. He fed off the energy of 44,287 fans gathered at Citi Field for the Mets' first NLCS game since 2006 and first-ever playoff game against the Cubs. 
For the sixth time this season, and the first time since Aug. 11, Harvey pitched into the eighth. He struck out nine, egged on by those who stood and waved orange towels whenever he got to two strikes. 
Little could rattle Harvey -- not even a line drive off the bat of Dexter Fowler that smashed into his right triceps -- on the way to working past a handful of bad breaks to put the Mets in position to beat the Cubs. 
Harvey's first postseason start had been a slog. In a 13-7 victory over the Dodgers in NLDS Game 3, he never looked comfortable, allowing three runs in five innings. 
After the game, Terry Collins said he'd never seen him work harder to grind through a start. "I just saw a guy who hasn't been out there consistently," Collins later said.
